title: Convolvulus scammonia
text:
Convolvulus scammonia, known commonly as scammony, is a bindweed native to the countries of the eastern part of the <a href="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a> basin; it grows in bushy waste places, from <a href="Syria">Syria</a> in the south to the <a href="Crimea">Crimea</a> in the north, its range extending westward to the <a href="Greek%20islands">Greek islands</a>, but not to northern <a href="Africa">Africa</a> or <a href="Italy">Italy</a>. It is a twining <a href="Perennial%20plant">perennial</a>, bearing <a href="flower">flower</a>s like those of "<a href="Convolvulus%20arvensis">Convolvulus arvensis</a>", and having irregularly arrow-shaped <a href="Leaf">leaves</a> and a thick fleshy root.
The dried juice, virgin scammony, obtained by incision of the living root, has been used in <a href="traditional%20medicine">traditional medicine</a> as "scammonium", but the variable quality of the drug has led to the employment of "scammoniae resina", which is obtained from the dried root by digestion with <a href="Alcohol%20%28chemistry%29">alcohol</a>. Upon consumption, the resin is inert until it has passed from the <a href="stomach">stomach</a> into the <a href="duodenum">duodenum</a>, where it meets the <a href="bile">bile</a>. A chemical reaction occurs between it and <a href="taurocholate">taurocholate</a> and <a href="glycocholate">glycocholate</a> in the bile, whereby it is converted into a powerful <a href="purgative">purgative</a> which in doses becomes a violent gastrointestinal irritant. Scammony kills both <a href="roundworm">roundworm</a> and <a href="tapeworm">tapeworm</a>, especially the former, and it was therefore used as an <a href="anthelmintic">anthelmintic</a>.
The principal bioactive component is the <a href="glucoside">glucoside</a> <a href="scammonin">scammonin</a> (also known as jalapin, molecular formula C34H56O16).
